nodes.name: DatasetStructured
nodes.description: This Node creates a DataFrame by reading data from HDFS, HIVE etc. The dataset has been defined earlier in Fire by using the Dataset Feature. As a user, you just have to select the Dataset of your interest.
nodes.details:
This Node creates a DataFrame by reading data from HDFS, HIVE etc.

The data has been defined earlier in Fire by using the Dataset Feature. As a user, you just have to select the Dataset of your interest.

nodes.name: Correlation
nodes.description: calculates the correlation between two series of data.
nodes.details:
This node calculates the correlation between two series of data in a common operation in Statistics.

More at Spark MLlib/ML docs page : spark.apache.org/docs/latest/mllib-statistics.html#correlations

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

nodes.name: Summary
nodes.description: Summary statistics provide useful information about sample data. eg: measures of spread.
nodes.details:
Summary statistics provides useful information about sample data. eg: measures of spread.

More at Spark MLlib/ML docs page : spark.apache.org/docs/latest/mllib-statistics.html#summary-statistics

Summary Node provides a table consist of informations such as number of non-null entries (count), mean, standard deviation, and minimum and maximum value for each numerical column.
nodes.examples:
A set of columns can be selected to display Summary on.

If SummaryStatistics node is configured to compute Statistical Summary for [Salary]

then outgoing Dataframe would be created as below displaying Statistical Summary values:

  • count : 8
  • mean : 11500
  • min : 10000
  • 25_percentile : 10000
  • 50_percentile : 11000
  • 75_percentile : 12000
  • max : 13000
  • stdev : 1195.229
  • variance : 1428571.429

nodes.name: Sticky Note
nodes.description: Allows capturing Notes on the Workflow

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: comment
fields.value:
DATA PROFILING

Using the below nodes,  we can discover, understand and organize our data

  • Columns Cardinality: To find the number of unique values in a string variable
  • Summary: Consist of informations such as number of non-null entries (count), mean, standard deviation, and minimum and maximum value for each numerical column
  • Null Values in Columns: Shows the number of Null values and its percentage against the total data length in the selected columns.
  • Corelation: Measures the relationship between two variables.
fields.title: Comment

nodes.name: Null Values In Column
nodes.description: Number of Null Values in Selected Columns.
nodes.details: This node identifies number of Null values and its percentage against the total data length in the selected columns.
nodes.examples:
A set of columns can be selected to display count of Null values on.

If NullValuesInColumn node is configured to display count of Null values in [EMP_CD], [EMP_NAME], [DEPT] and [AGE] columns from the incoming dataset

then outgoing Dataframe would be created as below displaying count of Null values in each column and it's percentage.

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: inputCols
fields.title: Column Names
fields.description: Name of columns for Number of Null Values Check

nodes.name: Columns Cardinality
nodes.description: Distribution of categorical data. Calculates the count of records for each unique value for the column specified.
nodes.details:
This node displays distribution of categorical data. Calculates the count of records for each unique value for the column specified.

This node facilitates selection of multiple String columns. Distribution of each column is displayed separately.
nodes.examples:
If ColumnsCardinality node is configured to display distribution on two columns i.e. [DEPT] and [SALARY_GRADE] from the incoming dataset
then output would be created as below:

Columns Unique Count

displaying count of unique values for each column


DEPT : 3
SALARY_GRADE : 3

Distribution of first selected column [DEPT]


HR : 3
SALES : 3
MANAGEMENT : 1

Distribution of second selected column [SALARY_GRADE]


HIGH : 3
MID : 2
LOW : 2

nodes.name: Drop Rows With Null
nodes.description: This node creates a new DataFrame by dropping rows containing null values
nodes.details: This node creates a new DataFrame by dropping rows containing NULL values in any of the columns.
nodes.examples:
Incoming Dataframe has following rows:

EMP_CD | EMP_NAME | DEPT | AGE
-------------------------------------------------------
E01 | DAVID | HR | 25
E05 | MARK | | 25
E02 | JOHN | SALES | 35
E03 | TONY | MARKETING |
E04 | MARTIN | MARKETING | 45

Incoming Dataframe has NULL values for two rows.
Using DropRowsWithNull node would result in below outgoing Dataframe created by dropping rows having NULL values in any of the columns:

EMP_CD | EMP_NAME | DEPT | AGE
-------------------------------------------------------
E01 | DAVID | HR | 25
E02 | JOHN | SALES | 35
E04 | MARTIN | MARKETING | 45
